summary.value:
Working memory is the system enabling temporary storage and manipulation of information . Previous studies have indicated that it is possible to retrospectively prioritize content in WM (Landman et al., 2003). A recent theoretical account (Myers et al., 2017) suggests retrospective prioritisation acts in several steps, first orienting towards a memory, then reconfiguring its representational state in the service of upcoming task demands. This model predicts that the expected form of recall affects the way information is coded in WM, perhaps in an action-oriented format similar to task-set preparation (Myers et al., 2017).If so, we might expect that code for prioritised content in WM to interact with new sensory input to produce a decision signal relative to the content in WM. This has previously been shown for explicitly instructed task sets (Printzlau et al., 2019).  Here I will test if that is similarly the case for prioritized content in WM. Participants will be between 18 and 40 years old and up to 60 participants will be recruited. 
In this study participants will encode two oriented bars into WM. They will be retrocued to focus on one of two objects, which will be relevant to a subsequent two-alternative forced choice clockwise-or anticlockwise decision. This will be referred to as the inducer task. During the delay of the inducer task, they will be asked to perform a diagnostic task, identifying the colour (blue or pink) of 2,4 or 6 objects with random orientations in sequence using the same response keys as for the inducer task. The colour and orientation of the objects on the diagnostic task will mean their responses will either be congruent (same response key) or incongruent (different response key) relative to the correct response for the retro-cued object on the inducer task. I will analyse correct inducer trials. I predict that in t-tests of reaction times and accuracy in the diagnostic task between trials that are congruent or incongruent, performance will be significantly worse (slower reaction times, lower accuracy) in the incongruent cases. If my hypothesis is correct it will suggest that there is an interaction between prioritised content in working memory and new sensory input during the task.

registration_responses.summary:
Working memory is the system enabling temporary storage and manipulation of information . Previous studies have indicated that it is possible to retrospectively prioritize content in WM (Landman et al., 2003). A recent theoretical account (Myers et al., 2017) suggests retrospective prioritisation acts in several steps, first orienting towards a memory, then reconfiguring its representational state in the service of upcoming task demands. This model predicts that the expected form of recall affects the way information is coded in WM, perhaps in an action-oriented format similar to task-set preparation (Myers et al., 2017).If so, we might expect that code for prioritised content in WM to interact with new sensory input to produce a decision signal relative to the content in WM. This has previously been shown for explicitly instructed task sets (Printzlau et al., 2019).  Here I will test if that is similarly the case for prioritized content in WM. Participants will be between 18 and 40 years old and up to 60 participants will be recruited. 
In this study participants will encode two oriented bars into WM. They will be retrocued to focus on one of two objects, which will be relevant to a subsequent two-alternative forced choice clockwise-or anticlockwise decision. This will be referred to as the inducer task. During the delay of the inducer task, they will be asked to perform a diagnostic task, identifying the colour (blue or pink) of 2,4 or 6 objects with random orientations in sequence using the same response keys as for the inducer task. The colour and orientation of the objects on the diagnostic task will mean their responses will either be congruent (same response key) or incongruent (different response key) relative to the correct response for the retro-cued object on the inducer task. I will analyse correct inducer trials. I predict that in t-tests of reaction times and accuracy in the diagnostic task between trials that are congruent or incongruent, performance will be significantly worse (slower reaction times, lower accuracy) in the incongruent cases. If my hypothesis is correct it will suggest that there is an interaction between prioritised content in working memory and new sensory input during the task.

attributes.title: The effect of resistance training compared to aerobic training on peripheral irisin levels in adults: a meta-analysis
attributes.description: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis on the effect of resistance training compared to aerobic training impact the circulating irisin (plasma irisin or serum irisin) in adults?

q1.value: The effect of resistance training compared to aerobic training on peripheral irisin levels in adults: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

q3.value: Strong evidence suggests the exercise-induced release of irisin into the blood has potential as a therapeutic treatment for cognitive decline and dementia. It is therefore important to fully understand the most effective training interventions to maximise circulating levels of this myokine. Several studies have compared the effect of aerobic and resistance training interventions on circulating irisin concentrations but no systematic review and meta- analysis of these studies has been carried out to date.

q4.value: Resistance training will induce higher plasma irisin levels compared with aerobic training after acute bouts of the exercise intervention.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Not applicable as this is a systematic review/meta-analysis.

question.value: This study is a systematic review and potential meta-analysis that seeks to review the current peer-reviewed literature to quantify the effects of resistance training compared to aerobic training interventions on circulating irisin levels in adults. The aim of the systematic review will be to improve our understanding of whether the type of exercise intervention prescribed effects the circulating irisin levels in adults.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: As a systematic review and meta analysis, we will be accessing the summary data reported in the eligible papers.

q13.value: As a systematic review sample size is not applicable.

question.value: Not applicable.
Means and standard deviations of circulating irisin in the two exercise conditions, as well as confidence level will be extracted.
If possible, a meta-analysis will be performed on the data.

Following screening, full text articles will be retrieved and independently assessed by two reviewers (JN and MS) for eligibility according to the outlined inclusion criteria. Where there is inconsistency in article inclusions, an independent assessment will be made by a third blinded assessor (DJ) and the article will be included/excluded according to the opinion of the majority. Reference lists of eligible articles will be manually assessed for additional references and corresponding authors will be contacted in the instance where full-text is not available.

The review authors will independently assess the risk of bias using the PEDRo scale. Each of the reviewers will rate the eligible articles on each of the 11 items of the scale and provide a total score between 0 to 11 for each article. Any disagreements between reviewers scores will be identified, with the two review authors discussing their differences before reaching an agreement. If such agreement can't be obtained, a third senior reviewer will be consulted so that a consensus can be reached. Information on the risk of bias will be used for inclusion into any meta-analysis and discussion of the results of these papers, whereby greater emphasis will be provided on those studies with a low risk of bias

Data from the eligible studies will be extracted using a standardised data extraction sheet. Extracted data will include: sample size, sample characteristics (e.g. age, sex, BMI, body composition, VO2Max, strength), authors and publication year, details of the intervention (exercise form, intensity and duration) and the methods for irisin measurement and timing after the intervention for blood sampling. We will also provide the standardised difference in means to determine the effect size, as expressed as Cohen’s d, for each study. The data for determining Cohen’s d will include the sample sizes, means and standard deviations of circulating irisin in the two exercise conditions, as well as confidence level.

For studies that included similar outcome measures, results will be pooled in order to perform a random effects meta-analysis. The Q statistic and I² test will be used to examine the heterogeneity among all studies. We will conduct a sensitivity analyses on study quality, intervention component design and for comparator group (negative compared to passive). (authors and publication year), details of the intervention (exercise form, intensity and duration) and the methods for irisin measurement.

q21.value: If a meta-analysis can be performed, standardised weighted mean differences or weighted mean differences will be calculated where applicable.

q23.value: Where there is missing data, a request will be sent to the study authors to provide any missing data.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Textual responses might be coded and analysed in order to systematically evaluate people's reasoning underlying their choices. 

Paired-samples t-tests may be used to explore within-condition differences in the ratings of the two versions of the closing arguments.

sample.value: We seek a sample size of 100 participants in each condition, so a total sample size of 200 participants (post-exclusions).

analyses.value:
Binomial tests will be used to explore the proportion of choices (relating to which version of the closing argument to deliver) within each condition. Chi-square tests of independence will be carried out on the proportion of choices (relating to which version of the closing argument to deliver) between the two conditions.

Furthermore, independent samples t-tests will be used to explore between-condition differences in the ratings of each dimension (eg. persuasiveness) of the closing arguments.

outliers.value: No outliers will be excluded. Participants will be excluded if and only if they demonstrate a clear failure to complete the task. Note that we do not anticipate having to include any participants.

dependent.value: We have two dependent variables. The first DV is the choice of which closing argument to deliver (dichotomous choice variable). The second  DV is the ratings of the two versions of the closing arguments (7 point Likert-scale statements ranging from 'strongly disagree' to 'strongly agree').

conditions.value: 2 conditions. Participants will be tasked as either the defence lawyer or the prosecution lawyers and view two pertinent versions of the closing argument they could choose to deliver.

hypothesis.value:
In this project, we are asking if people have a general 'purpose bias' in various stages of the legal/criminal process. In this particular study, we are asking whether this 'purpose bias' is present at later stages of the legal/criminal process; namely, when evaluating closing arguments in criminal trials.

Participants will read a brief (4-5 sentence) introduction to a criminal case. They are then tasked as either the defence lawyer or the prosecution lawyer and asked to read two different versions of the closing argument they could deliver in court (one version using 'motive-centred' arguments and one using 'opportunity-centred' arguments) to persuade the jury of the defendant's guilt/innocence. 

After having read the two versions participants are asked to choose which version of the closing argument, they would deliver in court to persuade the jury. Subsequently, participants are asked to rate each version on the following dimensions: persuasiveness, completeness and believability. 

We expect that participants tasked as prosecutors will prefer to deliver the closing statement that contains information relating to 'purpose' (e.g. motive-centred). Conversely we expect that participants tasked as defence lawyers will display less purpose-bias by choosing to deliver the closing argument centred on opportunity/mechanistic information significantly more.

registration_responses.hypothesis:
In this project, we are asking if people have a general 'purpose bias' in various stages of the legal/criminal process. In this particular study, we are asking whether this 'purpose bias' is present at later stages of the legal/criminal process; namely, when evaluating closing arguments in criminal trials.

Participants will read a brief (4-5 sentence) introduction to a criminal case. They are then tasked as either the defence lawyer or the prosecution lawyer and asked to read two different versions of the closing argument they could deliver in court (one version using 'motive-centred' arguments and one using 'opportunity-centred' arguments) to persuade the jury of the defendant's guilt/innocence. 

After having read the two versions participants are asked to choose which version of the closing argument, they would deliver in court to persuade the jury. Subsequently, participants are asked to rate each version on the following dimensions: persuasiveness, completeness and believability. 

We expect that participants tasked as prosecutors will prefer to deliver the closing statement that contains information relating to 'purpose' (e.g. motive-centred). Conversely we expect that participants tasked as defence lawyers will display less purpose-bias by choosing to deliver the closing argument centred on opportunity/mechanistic information significantly more.

attributes.title: Trust in experts during an epidemic
attributes.description:
Trust in science is extremely important in times of epidemics.
Policy makers who face rapidly evolving situations with few available policy tools need to understand first how trust in experts evolves while an epidemic is underway, in order to prevent small-scale outbreaks from escalating into large-scale emergencies, and second how to effectively reduce misperceptions and increase the reception of scientific information among a vast public.
This project seeks to understand these processes in the context of the unfolding of the real-time, high-impact epidemic of the COVID-19 in Italy. The digital revolution, brought about by the diffusion of the internet and mobile phones, together with the large-scale adoption of online social networking platforms, offers opportunities to track the evolution of trust in real-time. This paper leverages this potential by drawing on data collected from three online social networking platforms -- Twitter, Facebook, and Telegram -- to: 1) describe how trust in science evolves during an epidemic, and 2) study how to curb misinformation in times of epidemics.

attributes.title: Protocol for Qualitative Systematic Review
attributes.description: Details of steps for the qualitative systematic review

q1.value: Describing the competences of regulatory scientists in sub-Sharan Africa for regulatory registration and inspection to improve the safety, quality and efficacy of medical products– A qualitative systematic review.

q2.value: Abigail Ekeigwe, Kari L Clase, Steve Byrn, Paddy Shivanand, Bethany McGowan, Loran Carleton Parker

q3.value:
The purpose of this study is to describe a competency framework for regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa involved in regulatory registration and inspections to improve the safety, quality and efficacy of medical products. It will involve a qualitative systematic review of the literature to identify key competences. 

Background
 Regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa is the population being studied in this research.
There is no documentation in the literature of competencies required of regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the literature shows that inadequate competent regulatory scientists is a challenge to ensuring safe, quality and effective medical products in sub-Saharan Africa (Drugs for Neglected Diseases initiative, 2013; Ekeigwe, 2019; Ndomondo-Sigonda, Miot, Naidoo, Dodoo, & Kaale, 2017; World Health Organization, 2019). Despite efforts by developmental agencies such as the WHO, United Nations Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO), to train regulatory scientists, the problem still persists as noted in the 2019 report of Mckinsey & Company on “Should sub-Saharan Africa makes its own drugs” (Conway, Sabow, & Sun, 2019). Insufficient competent regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa is a persistent problem and there is a dearth of academic research in developing the competences of regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa. 
Competency frameworks are the substrate for effective development of the capacity of regulatory scientists and any other profession. (Drago, Shire, & Ekmekci, 2016). The absence of a competency framework has resulted in a wide skills range among regulators in sub-Saharan Africa; NMRAs are not at the same level in the regulation of medical products and difficulty in the ‘portability’ of regulatory scientists in the region. This in turn leads to huge variations in the efficient and effective regulation of medical products and therefore impairs access to safe, quality and effective medicinal products. (World Health Organization, 2010). Therefore, it is important to describe the competences required of regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa. This will serve as a template for developing curriculum, training, and recruitment processes. This review will focus on the competencies for regulatory scientists (regulators/regulatees) involved in the registration and inspection of medical products.

q4.value: What are the competence needs of regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa for regulatory registration and inspection?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Qualitative systematic review of the literature. Inclusion of literature in the study will be based on specific inclusion and exclusion criteria. The selected literature for the study will be checked for quality with the Joanna Briggs critical appraisal tool. Critical review of the literature to code themes will be done in vivo using the software NVivo.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data collection method - Search of databases and gray literature
Inclusion criteria – 
•	Must include a discussion of potential competences or competences in use or areas of needs for training and capacity development of regulatory scientists in the medical products industry.
•	Must be the most current version of the document
•	Must be the complete and final version of the document, not a draft or summary
Exclusion criteria – 
•	Literature not discussing potential competences or competences in use or areas of needs for training regulatory scientists in the medical products industry.
•	Documents in draft or summary version, or versions that have been replaced by another document.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated when searches through the database and gray literature does not give any new relevant literature

Drago, D. (2017). Promoting excellence in the regulatory. Regulatory Rapporteur, 14(10). 
Drago, D., Shire, S., & Ekmekci, O. (2016). Improving Regulatory Education: Can We Reconcile Employers’ Expectations With Academic Offerings? Therapeutic Innovation & Regulatory Science, 50(3), 330-336. doi:10.1177/2168479015620440

Critical review of the literature to code themes will be done in vivo using the software NVivo.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data collection method - Search of databases and gray literature
Inclusion criteria – 
•	Must include a discussion of potential competences or competences in use or areas of needs for training and capacity development of regulatory scientists in the medical products industry.
•	Must be the most current version of the document
•	Must be the complete and final version of the document, not a draft or summary
Exclusion criteria – 
•	Literature not discussing potential competences or competences in use or areas of needs for training regulatory scientists in the medical products industry.
•	Documents in draft or summary version, or versions that have been replaced by another document.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated when searches through the database and gray literature does not give any new relevant literature

Drago, D. (2017). Promoting excellence in the regulatory. Regulatory Rapporteur, 14(10). 
Drago, D., Shire, S., & Ekmekci, O. (2016). Improving Regulatory Education: Can We Reconcile Employers’ Expectations With Academic Offerings? Therapeutic Innovation & Regulatory Science, 50(3), 330-336. doi:10.1177/2168479015620440
Drugs for Neglected Diseases initiative. (2013). The

registration_responses.q1: Describing the competences of regulatory scientists in sub-Sharan Africa for regulatory registration and inspection to improve the safety, quality and efficacy of medical products– A qualitative systematic review.
registration_responses.q2: Abigail Ekeigwe, Kari L Clase, Steve Byrn, Paddy Shivanand, Bethany McGowan, Loran Carleton Parker
registration_responses.q3:
The purpose of this study is to describe a competency framework for regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa involved in regulatory registration and inspections to improve the safety, quality and efficacy of medical products. It will involve a qualitative systematic review of the literature to identify key competences. 

Background
 Regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa is the population being studied in this research.
There is no documentation in the literature of competencies required of regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the literature shows that inadequate competent regulatory scientists is a challenge to ensuring safe, quality and effective medical products in sub-Saharan Africa (Drugs for Neglected Diseases initiative, 2013; Ekeigwe, 2019; Ndomondo-Sigonda, Miot, Naidoo, Dodoo, & Kaale, 2017; World Health Organization, 2019). Despite efforts by developmental agencies such as the WHO, United Nations Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO), to train regulatory scientists, the problem still persists as noted in the 2019 report of Mckinsey & Company on “Should sub-Saharan Africa makes its own drugs” (Conway, Sabow, & Sun, 2019). Insufficient competent regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa is a persistent problem and there is a dearth of academic research in developing the competences of regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa. 
Competency frameworks are the substrate for effective development of the capacity of regulatory scientists and any other profession. (Drago, Shire, & Ekmekci, 2016). The absence of a competency framework has resulted in a wide skills range among regulators in sub-Saharan Africa; NMRAs are not at the same level in the regulation of medical products and difficulty in the ‘portability’ of regulatory scientists in the region. This in turn leads to huge variations in the efficient and effective regulation of medical products and therefore impairs access to safe, quality and effective medicinal products. (World Health Organization, 2010). Therefore, it is important to describe the competences required of regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa. This will serve as a template for developing curriculum, training, and recruitment processes. This review will focus on the competencies for regulatory scientists (regulators/regulatees) involved in the registration and inspection of medical products.
registration_responses.q4: What are the competence needs of regulatory scientists in sub-Saharan Africa for regulatory registration and inspection?
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: The effect of N-acetylcysteine ​​in patients with bipolar depression: a systematic review and a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials

q1.value: The effect of N-acetylcysteine ​​in patients with bipolar depression: a systematic review and a meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials.

q3.value: The management of depressive phase of bipolar disorder appears to be complicated. To date, there is little available evidence of effective treatment choices for the depressive phase. Additionally, it has been showed that after prolonged use of medication, drug tolerance was encountered. The existing therapies with antipsychotic drugs and mood stabilizers are mainly effective in treating mania rather than depression while using antidepressants can induce phase switching. Hence, the discovery of new therapeutic agents for bipolar disorder, and specifically for bipolar depression, is a necessity. There are a significant number of studies that have examined the efficacy of n-acetylcysteine (NAC) ​​in bipolar disorder. However, the results are conflicting. Given the lack of many alternative treatment choices, the purpose of this study is to systematically review and analyze the existing evidence regarding the effect of NAC on bipolar depression.

q4.value:
We will evaluate  whether the administration of n-acetylcysteine ​​as an adjuvant therapy for bipolar disorder, compared to standard theatment alone, will improve the symptoms and/or functional status of bipolar patients with a recent episode of depression.
Although the pathophysiological mechanism of bipolar disorder remains generally unknown, cases related to glutathione metabolism disorders, increased systemic inflammation and mitochondrial disorders. The possible mechanisms of action of N-acetylcysteine, with the anti-inflammatory properties that causes reduction of oxidative stress, increase in glutathione levels, and increase of mitochondrial functionallity, make it a potential therapeutic agent for bipolar disorder.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will perform a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
We will perform a systematic review on electronic databases Pubmed, Cochrane Central, Scopus, Clinical Trials, and Google for grey literature. Additionally, reference lists of included studies will also be searched.

The inclusion criteria for this SR&MA will include:
1) diagnosed with bipolar disorder according to DSM or ICD criteria
2) with a current depressive episode

Articles in languages other than English will be excluded.

The measured variables, depending on published data available, will include symptoms, functioning, and quality of life scales:
1) MADRS: Montgomery Asberg Depression Rating Scale
2) YMRS: Young Mania Rating Scale
3) BDRS: Bipolar Depression Rating Scale
4) CGI: Clinical Global Impression 
5) GAF: Global Assessment of Functioning Scale
6) SOFAS: Social and Occupational Functioning Assessment Scale
7) SLICE/LIFE: Streamlined Longitudinal Interview Clinical Evaluation from the Longitudinal Interval Follow-up Evaluation
8) LIFE/RIFT: Longitudinal Interval Follow-up Evaluation-Range of Impaired function tool
9) QLESQ: Quality of Life Enjoyment and Satisfaction Questionnaire

The random effects model will be used for statistical analysis of the data, which takes into account possible heterogeneity between studies. The heterogeneity will be assessed using the Cochran's Q test and I^2. For continuous data, the mean difference will be calculated, while for binary data the odds ratio will be calculated. The data will be analyzed using the command metacont, metabin, and forest of the R statistical software.

q25.value: Risk of bias assesment will be performed with the risk of bias tool 2.0 and Grade will be applied to evaluate the strength of evidence.

attributes.title: Voting in Adverse Conditions: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Chile

q1.value: Voting in Adverse Conditions: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Chile

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Citizens living in the developing world are frequently exposed to adverse conditions generated by negative shocks. These events tend to reduce voters’ incomes and diminish their living conditions. The 2010 earthquake in Chile, the 2017 floods in Peru, the rise of crime in Venezuela since 2005, and the spread of international criminal gangs in Central America are examples of particular negative circumstances that have affected citizens’ standard of living in different developing countries. We know that negative events such as natural disasters and crime can have an impact on electoral outcomes (Achen and Bartels, 2004; Marshall, 2015). Why do citizens change their political behavior after negative shocks? I plan to study how these adverse events change voters’ political preferences. In particular, I focus on how natural disasters and crime victimization make candidates with certain labels more attractive to voters than others. Do crime victims tend to prefer right-wing candidates? Can natural disasters increase the probability of voting for left-wing politicians? The current literature about the political consequences of negative events tends to focus on voters’ retrospective assessments of incumbents’ performance. The main argument is that citizens (mis)attribute responsibilities after negative shocks, and punish or reward incumbents according to that (mis)evaluation. However, this approach fails to notice the importance of prospective political preferences. I hold that citizens, besides blaming or gratifying incumbents for their response to a negative event, are also selecting political authorities that can enhance their welfare. Victims focus on improving their living conditions after a negative shock, which leads them to pay attention to particular policy issues that can help them to achieve that goal. As a consequence, affected voters are more likely to select candidates that are better suited to address these new policy concerns. How do voters know which candidate matches their new policy preferences? Victims can exploit certain labels to identify the politician that is more likely to implement the policies they most care about. For example, ideological labels (e.g., left and right) can work as informational shortcuts to connect candidates with simple policy outcomes (e.g., welfare and iron-fist policies). Party labels can also work as heuristics in places where ideology is less salient.

q16.value: Based on this argument, I present the following hypotheses. First, the negative event will modify voters’ policy preferences. 1. I expect that disaster victims will be more likely to support the distribution of welfare policies by the government. 2. I expect that crime victims will be more likely to support the use of iron-fist policies by the government. Second, these new policy preferences will lead voters to support candidates with particular ideological labels. 3. I expect that disaster victims will be more likely to vote for left-wing candidates. 4. I expect that crime victims will be more likely to vote for right-wing candidates. Third, the previous expectations can only be true if voters are able to connect simple policy issues with ideological labels. 5. I expect that a majority of respondents will link welfare policies with left-wing candidates. 6. I expect that a majority of respondents will link iron-fist policies with right-wing candidates. I will conduct this study in Chile. This country presents the ideal conditions since disasters and crime are not rare events. Natural catastrophes are quite common across the entire national territory (Hewitt, 2014), and according to official data, 27% of households have been a crime victim in the last 12 months. Additionally, voters do have the capacity to place parties/coalitions on the ideological spectrum (Calvo and Murillo, 2012). Therefore, ideological labels can work as informational shortcuts to make informed decisions.

q17.value: This study is based on a face-to-face survey. Respondents will need to imagine they are disaster or crime victims. I follow a two-step procedure to select participants. In the first step, I select the county that better predicts the electoral results in Chile. There have been six presidential elections in this country since the transition to democracy (1989, 1993, 1999, 2005, 2009, and 2013), and 32 candidates have competed in these elections. I compare the presidential electoral results in the 345 municipalities in Chile with the national electoral results. The analysis is straightforward; for each municipality, I sum up the absolute differences between this county and the national results for the 32 candidates that ran in the six presidential elections. The municipality with the lowest absolute difference was Cerrillos. This county is part of the Greater Santiago conurbation. Table 1 reports the vote share between Chile and Cerrillos, and it is useful to visually inspect how this municipality is an excellent predictor of the national electoral results (see document attached). In summary, the goal of this analysis is to avoid implementing the survey in counties that are outliers and do not represent the average political preferences in Chile. In a second step, I will select respondents within Cerrillos. This municipality can be divided into four neighborhoods: Lo Errázuriz, Divino Maestro, Villa México, and Cerrillos. One enumerator will be assigned to each neighborhood, and within this area, we will use a random walk to select every 3rd household in a given street. It is expected that enumerators will cover the entire neighborhood by the end of the survey implementation. This study will be conducted by four enumerators in August 2017. The questionnaire can be divided into five sections. The first part will ask for general political opinions: evaluation of the president, voting preferences, etc. The second part will ask for respondents’ background characteristics: age, education, etc. The third part will attempt to learn if citizens are capable of connecting simple policy ideas with ideological labels. In particular, it will ask participants to link social and iron-fist policies with left or right-wing politicians. The fourth part will use an experimental design by providing three different scenarios to participants: to be a disaster victim, to be a crime victim, and a control condition (no extra information). The disaster condition will say: "Imagine you are a disaster victim. Yesterday there was a 9.0 earthquake in Santiago that destroyed an important part of your house and your belongings. Please take five seconds to think about the personal consequences of this disaster [WAIT FIVE SECONDS]." The crime condition will say: "Imagine you are a crime victim. Yesterday three people violently entered your house and stole you important and expensive belongings. Please take five seconds to think about the personal consequences of this crime [WAIT FIVE SECONDS]." The control condition will not provide information about a disaster or a crime. The outcome for disaster victims is: "Taking into account the post-disaster context, do you think that authorities to help victims of natural disasters should distribute social policies or that every person is responsible for his/her own welfare?" The outcome for crime victims is: "Taking into account the post-crime context, do you think that authorities to reduce crime should apply iron-fist policies or should focus on rehabilitation of criminals? Participants in the control condition will receive both questions (but without the phrase: "taking into account the post-disaster/crime context"). The fifth part will use a conjoint experiment to measure respondents’ electoral choices. Participants will be asked to decide between two (non-real) candidates that will be competing for the position of president in the 2017 elections. Respondents will see information about three attributes of these two presidential candidates: ideology (left and right), profession (gardener, teacher, engineer), and age (30, 40, 50). These attributes will be randomly chosen to generate the candidates’ profiles (Hainmueller, Hopkins and Yamamoto, 2014). Each of the respondents will have to evaluate five pairs of profiles and select one candidate for president. The treatment condition will be repeated by the enumerator. I include ideology as an attribute because this is a relevant political label in Chile, and should help voters to identify the candidate that will implement the policies they most care about. I also include education and age because these attributes can provide signals of candidates’ competencies to address the consequences of a negative shock. These two characteristics might be seen as valence issues by voters. I use the fourth part of the survey to compute statistical power. In order to achieve 80% power, I will need to have a sample size of at least 871 subjects (disaster treatment, crime treatment, and control). Regarding hypotheses 1 and 2, I will regress the outcome (policy preferences) on a treatment indicator (1: disaster or crime victim, 0: control). I will also include a model with controls that should predict the outcome (e.g., age, education, and ideology). I expect that the disaster treatment will increase support for welfare policies. Meanwhile, the crime treatment will increase support for iron-fist policies. Regarding hypotheses 3 and 4, the empirical strategy will be based on an interaction between the candidates’ attributes (conjoint experiment) and the hypothetical scenarios (vignette experiment). This interaction (see document attached) describes the change in effect of the candidates’ attributes between control and treatment conditions (disaster or crime victim). I expect that the disaster treatment will increase support for left-wing candidates. Meanwhile, the crime treatment will increase support for right-wing candidates. Regarding hypotheses 5 and 6, I need to show that a majority of respondents (>50%) are able to link social policies with left-wing politicians and iron-fist policies with right-wing politicians.
